item.title: London calling
item.dc:creator: Cara Harrington
item.content:encoded:
Monday we returned home from 10 days in the UK.  We stayed with my Great Aunt Bernie and Great Uncle Jim at their lovely house in Kent, Treetop.  Both kids loved exploring the place, and Maggie enjoyed being able to have private art lessons courtesy of Jim.  I have many fond memories of visiting Treetop as a child, and hope Maggie and Graeme will too! We were able to do some day trips, despite a variety of illnesses that struck down each one of us at some stage! While traveling with kids definitely had it’s struggles (note: the enclosed capsules of the London Eye are not ideal for a screaming 14 month old….), I think we all enjoyed being in England, and I’m sure to be fielding many questions for when we’ll be returning – especially as Maggie has already asked about when we’ll see baby Alexa again!

And we’re off!

London
We took the train up to the city twice, the first time to visit with Rachel and her family, and Gemma and her family, and the second time to tick off items on Maggie’s bucket list: ride the top of a double decker bus, see Big Ben, go on the London Eye, and see Peter Pan.

                   

Hever Castle
Maggie also wanted to “see a real Queen’s castle”.

    

Rochester
First photo was taken by Maggie – nice to have a budding photographer in the family!

       

Kew Gardens
Not many photos – but beautiful park with a treetop walkway the kids loved and a fantastic playground.

Treetop
The real highlight of the trip was the time spent with family – the kids meeting their great, great aunt and uncle, us getting to meet baby Lexie, and lots of time spent just catching up!

item.title: Another holiday season in the books
item.dc:creator: Cara Harrington
item.content:encoded: We celebrated Graeme’s 1st and Maggie’s 4th Christmas with no shortage of candy canes, caroling, and cheer! Maggie was really into Christmas this year and it made everything all the more exciting – from writing her list, to shopping for her brother and daddy, to posing for the holiday card photo, she did it all with a smile on her face and a skip in her step.  We got to meet Santa, see the Nutcracker her dance school put on, decorate gingerbread houses, and see lots of family and friends – while it’s always sad when the holidays are over, ours were so jam-packed that I’m looking forward to a quiet January!

item.title: Why I’m With Her.
item.dc:creator: Cara Harrington
item.content:encoded:
Ahead of Tuesday’s election, I want to get this out.  I know this blog doesn’t get much traffic, but I hope one day when Maggie and Graeme are older, they appreciate the photos and posts to tell them about our life (printed photo albums are far too hard to keep up with, and that baby book I never filled in…yea…).  So for them, and all the kids out there who are too young to vote but who’s lives will be forever affected by the results of this election, here’s why I’m with Hillary.

I’m with her…because raising human beings is hard enough without having to explain why our president is allowed to name call.

I’m with her…because parents deserve to have paid leave to take care of a new baby, an aging parent, or a sick kid.

I’m with her…because immigrants make our country a better place and should be welcomed with open arms.

I’m with her…because getting sick should not put you into bankruptcy.

I’m with her…because women deserve the right to makes their own decisions about their own bodies.

I’m with her…because we need Supreme Court justices who will continue to protect the lives and interests of women, minorities, LGBTQ, and other under-represented populations.

I’m with her…because education is one of the most important things we can give the next generation, and we need to do better.

I’m with her…because I’m an ally who believes that you should be able to love whoever you want, be whoever you want, and live the life you choose.

I’m with her…because women work just as hard (sometimes harder) than their male counterparts and should be compensated equally.

I’m with her…because my vision of America is a united one, one where our differences raise us up rather than tearing us apart.

I’m with her…because I believe in science, climate change is real, and we need to power our lives in ways that are more efficient, effective, and better for the environment.

I’m with her…because she is the MOST qualified person to ever run for office and will continue to push our country forward.

I’m with her…because “Madam President” should be a term used so frequently, it’s no longer novel.

I’m with her…because not just our daughters, but our sons, need to live in a country where a woman can rise to the highest office to show them that women can and should do whatever they want in life.

I’m with her…because LOVE should always trump hate.

item.title: Graeme’s Newborn Shoot
item.dc:creator: Cara Harrington
item.content:encoded:
We had Lyndsay over in early July to capture some photos of our new expanded family – I absolutely love how they came out!  Maggie is so in love with Graeme and you can really see it in these photos, I love watching her interact with him and her gentle touch makes me love her even more than I thought possible! I know this phase won’t last forever – talk to me when he is big enough to start getting into her stuff – but I’ll relish it while it’s here!

Here are some favorites:

item.title: Graeme has arrived!
item.dc:creator: Cara Harrington
item.content:encoded:
So it all started 10 days earlier…I spent a night barely sleeping as my whole body was itchier than I had ever experienced.  I put a call in to the doctor who recommended going in for some blood work, hmmm. Monday’s blood work followed with an appointment Tuesday with my dr.  At this point, we weren’t sure what was going on, but there was a chance of an issue called obstetric cholestasis and so began the week of stress.  We went back and forth with whether or not there was a need to induce, had more blood work and ultrasounds every other day, all while waiting on ONE test to come back that can take 5-7 days (why any blood test takes that long, I have no idea!).  Finally came the morning of Maggie’s recital and the day we were due to find out for sure, yes or no on an induction.  A morning call from my doctor said, we’re in the clear – we’ll wait for you to go into labor naturally.  So off we went to Maggie’s recital relieved that everything was okay.  At intermission, I check my phone and have a voicemail from my doctor “nothing urgent, but call me when you can” – turns out after a day of discussing my case with some other physicians and diving closely into my blood work, they decided I was, in fact, a candidate for an induction and…could I come in tonight?

We drove Maggie home, put her to bed, packed up the car and headed for the hospital, leaving Maggie with Nana.  At this point, they were happy to induce and see if my body would go into labor itself – after a C-section with Maggie, I was more than happy to try and avoid that scenario again.

We started the induction and settled in for a long night/few days….after about 12 hours, we decided the induction wouldn’t work, Graeme wasn’t responding well to the contractions and they didn’t want to push it, and so a repeat c-section was planned and by 1:31pm on June 13, we welcomed our baby boy!

Introducing Graeme Robert Harrington, weighing 6lbs 11oz and measuring 19 inches, and as scrumptious as they come!

item.title: Waiting on baby brother
item.dc:creator: Cara Harrington
item.content:encoded:
We’re less than 5 weeks from the due date for Baby Boy Harrington and we’re all getting ready.  Maggie loves to “listen” to my belly and tell me things like “the new baby says he wants to come out” or put her finger in my belly button and giggle that the baby is tickling her – it’s all really sweet and quite a change from her initial reaction!  As excited as she has become, I know she has NO idea what is really coming and how different life will be, but I know in the long run it’ll be worth the initial struggles to have a sibling, a friend for life.

Although I didn’t bother when pregnant with Maggie, we decided to do some maternity photos this time round – mainly because I wanted to capture some last photos before we became a family of 4.  We used Lyndsay Hannah Photography who I can’t say enough about! She is a friend of a friend who, despite only doing this for a short time professionally, is super talented – plus a really sweet person, which always helps!  Maggie had a blast and Elm Bank in Wellesley is going to be a new destination for us – their children’s garden was amazing.  Here are a few favorites!

item.title: ¡Bienvenidos a Miami!
item.dc:creator: Cara Harrington
item.content:encoded:
After seeing the Stuyck family over the summer, Maggie never stopped talking about her friend Pia and when we would see her again.  We figured, what better time to head to Miami than in the middle of winter here in Boston!

We arrived on the last Thursday in January and was able to meet up with my old colleague Harry in Ft Lauderdale.  Despite the rainy weather, we managed to grab lunch by the ocean and had some time catching up.  After lunch, Harry drove us to Coconut Grove to start the weekend with the Stuycks.

Maggie and Pia slipped right back into their BFF ways – again, you would have thought they had spent a huge amount of time together previously, not 36 hours!  We unfortunately didn’t have great weather the first few days so spent time hanging around the house, visited the local Children’s Museum, explored their neighborhood, and as always with toddlers, got in some park time.  On Saturday we finally made it to the beach, and while it wasn’t swimming weather, the sun and sand was all we needed to feel like we were on holiday!

The trip, as most, was too short, and we can’t wait to see Pia, Rafa, Chrissy, and Jaime again – most likely it’ll be after our new addition arrives so Pia will be able to impart all her big sister wisdom on Maggie!

item.title: Happy Holidays
item.dc:creator: Cara Harrington
item.content:encoded:
We had a wonderful holiday season – Maggie really started to understand what was going on this year and was so excited.  We embraced every opportunity to celebrate the holidays including a night to Edaville Railroad, a toddler-friendly showing of the Nutcracker by the Metrowest Ballet and of course, lots of visits with friends and family!

The lead up….

  

Christmas!

and New Years!

item.title: 5 years?!
item.dc:creator: Cara Harrington
item.content:encoded:
Somehow, 5 years of marriage have passed – between travel, buying a house, and having a child, things have definitely changed from that day back in 2010, yet it still feels like only yesterday!

Happy anniversary to us!

item.title: Erin Go Bragh
item.dc:creator: Cara Harrington
item.content:encoded:
Having not been on a European vacation since Maggie arrived, we decided to get our feet wet by traveling with the McArdles to Ireland for 10 days.  We spent time in Dublin, Armagh, and Roscommon, with day visits to Dun Laoghaire and Galway.

Dublin

After arriving Friday morning, we spent the next 3 days being tourists in Dublin – visiting the Guinness Storehouse, St Stephen’s Green (multiple times for the playground!), Grafton Street, and lots more through the Dublin Road Train tour.  It was definitely a different experience visiting Dublin with a toddler – all the places (read: pubs) I’d visited in my most recent trips didn’t seem to be the best places for Maggie! We did find Dublin to be really child friendly though and even when we ended up in a pub, they were really welcoming!

Maggie having a blast touring Dublin

Dun Laoghaire

We had planned on visiting Dun Laoghaire for a day anyways, but when our great uncle Tom passed away, we headed down on the day of the wake.  We only had a few hours to kill, and the weather was not on our side, but we still managed to walk the pier and get ice cream at Teddy’s. Though it was for a sad occasion, we were able to see family that we hadn’t planned on seeing and it was great to be able to catch up.  Uncle Tom was a great man and will be very sorely missed.

 

Armagh (Northern Ireland)

After the day in DL, we headed up north to the McArdle farm.  We spent the next few days here visiting with the cows, walking the fields, going to Gosford Forest Park, and doing some shopping.  It was great to finally get to see the famed farm that we had all heard so much about!

Roscommon

On Thursday, we headed to Nana’s hometown of Roscommon to stay with the Fallon family.  It’s been a while since I’ve been back to Roscommon, and while much has changed, seeing “Nana’s castle” and the Moran grave brought back lots of memories of trips to Ireland as a kid.  We had a visit from our other cousin Ciara and her 2 little girls which was a great day (though poor Phelan was well outnumbered – 6 girls to 1 boy!).

The Fallon’s home was the perfect place to visit, kid-friendly, lots of space, and great hosts!  Maggie hasn’t stopped talking about Charlotte and Juliette – if only they lived closer!

 

Galway 

We popped into Galway for the day to see some family.  Was great to catch up with 2 of Nana’s sisters and lots of cousins – Pat finally understood why everyone is considered a “cousin”, even if technically they’re 2nd, 3rd, or even more distant, the extended Moran family is amazingly welcome to anyone who might share a drop of blood!  (We were too busy catching up to take any photos, but after brunch we wandered the city center a bit)

Fairy Day

The last day of the trip, we joined Steve, Goretti and the girls at a fundraiser Fairy Day – it was so sweet!! In honor of a local girl who was battling cancer, the fundraiser started last year and was a day of fun with fairies dancing, a magical walk through the woods, and lots of adorable little kids!

 

As with most vacations, it all went too quickly!! We’re missing everyone and already planning out the next time we can head over.  Maggie proved she’s a champion traveler with only taking 2 days on both ends to adjust to the time change and was great on the flights.
